## Before defining study aims & hypothesis

-   Betts MG , Hadley AS , Frey DW , et al. **When are hypotheses useful in ecology and evolution?**. Ecol Evol. 2021; 11: 5762--5776. \| [link](https://doi.org/10.1002/ece3.7365)

-   Popovic, et al. 2024. **Four principles for improved statistical ecology.** Methods in Ecology and Evolution, 00, 1--16. \| [link](https://besjournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/2041-210X.14270)

-   Book chapter by Gon√ßalves-Souza, T., Provete, D.B., Garey, M.V., da Silva, F.R., Albuquerque, U.P. (2019). **Going Back to Basics: How to Master the Art of Making Scientifically Sound Questions.** \| [link](https://doi.org/10.1007/978-1-4939-8919-5_7)

## Before collecting data

::: {.callout-tip appearance="simple"}
## Must read

-   Marshall, D. J. (2024). **Principles of experimental design for ecology and evolution**. Ecology Letters, 27(4), e14400. \| [link](https://doi.org/10.1111/ele.14400)
-   Kimmel, K., Dee, L. E., Avolio, M. L., & Ferraro, P. J. (2021). **Causal assumptions and causal inference in ecological experiments**. Trends in Ecology & Evolution, 36(12), 1141--1152. \| [link](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tree.2021.08.008)
:::

Also, think about experimental design, causal links and confounding factors:

-   Zeleny D. (2022). Blog Post: **Sampling design of ecological experiments.** \| [link](https://www.davidzeleny.net/anadat-r/doku.php/en:sampling_design)

-   Zeleny D. (2022). Blog Post: **Pseudoreplication & autocorrelation**. \| [link](https://davidzeleny.net/blog/2022/03/21/pseudoreplications-more-tricky-than-we-may-think/).

-   Byrnes, J. E. K., & Dee, L. E. (2024). **Causal inference with observational data and unobserved confounding variables**. \| [link](https://doi.org/10.1101/2024.02.26.582072)

Improve your management skills

-   BES Guide: "**Data Management** (2019) \| [link](https://www.britishecologicalsociety.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/BES-Guide-Data-Management-2019.pdf?utm_source=web&utm_medium=web&utm_campaign=better_science)

Going deeper:

-   Take a look at this great book: **The Turing Way handbook to reproducible, ethical and collaborative data science** \| [Link](https://book.the-turing-way.org/index.html)

## Before writing code

-   BES Guide: "**Reproducible Code** (2019) \| [link](https://www.britishecologicalsociety.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/BES-Guide-Reproducible-Code-2019.pdf?utm_source=web&utm_medium=web&utm_campaign=better_science)
-   How to choose the right license for code & data? \| [link](https://choosealicense.com/)

## Before analyzing data

Learn R ;)

-   Online book: McKinley et al. **Introduction to Data Analysis with R**. \| [link](https://datawithr.com/)
-   Online book: Da Silva et al. 2022. **Ecological analysis in R** (in portuguese) \| [link](https://analises-ecologicas.netlify.app/)

Define the purpose of your analysis

-   Tredennick, A. T., G. Hooker, S. P. Ellner, and P. B. Adler. 2021. **A practical guide to selecting models for exploration, inference, and prediction in ecology**. *Ecology* 102(6):e03336. \| [link](https://esajournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ecy.3336)

Key papers for avoiding statistical problems

-   Zuur, A.F., Ieno, E.N. and Elphick, C.S. (2010), **A protocol for data exploration to avoid common statistical problems**. Methods in Ecology and Evolution, 1: 3-14. \| [link](https://doi.org/10.1111/j.2041-210X.2009.00001.x)

-   Zuur, A.F. and Ieno, E.N. (2016), **A protocol for conducting and presenting results of regression-type analyses**. Methods Ecol Evol, 7: 636-645. \| [link](https://doi.org/10.1111/2041-210X.12577)

-   Harrison, X. A., Donaldson, L., Correa-Cano, M. E., Evans, J., Fisher, D. N., Goodwin, C. E. D., Robinson, B. S., Hodgson, D. J., & Inger, R. (2018). **A brief introduction to mixed effects modelling and multi-model inference in ecology**. PeerJ, 2018(5), 1--32 \| [link](https://doi.org/10.7717/peerj.4794)

How to interpret significance / pvalues?

-   Dushoff J, Kain MP, Bolker BM. **I can see clearly now: Reinterpreting statistical significance**. Methods Ecol Evol. 2019; 10: 756--759. \| [link](https://doi.org/10.1111/2041-210X.13159)

-   Blog post by Daniel Lakens: **Why p-values should be interpreted as p-values and not as measures of evidence** \| [link](http://daniellakens.blogspot.com/2021/11/why-p-values-should-be-interpreted-as-p.html)

Going further

-   **Data Science for Ecologists** - Courses and tutorials from Coding Club \| [link](https://ourcodingclub.github.io/)

-   Zeleny 2023. Blog: Analysis of community ecology data in R. \| [link](https://www.davidzeleny.net/anadat-r/doku.php/en:start)

### Before model selection

-   C. Sutherland, D. Hare, P. J. Johnson, D. W. Linden, R. A. Montgomery, and E. Droge (2023). **Practical advice on variable selection and reporting using Akaike information criterion.** Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences, vol. 290, no. 2007, Sep. 2023. \| [link](https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/10.1098/rspb.2023.1261)

## Before making figures

::: {.callout-tip appearance="simple"}
## Must read

-   Weissgerber, T. L., Milic, N. M., Winham, S. J., & Garovic, V. D. (2015). **Beyond Bar and Line Graphs: Time for a New Data Presentation Paradigm.** PLOS Biology, 13(4), e1002128 \| [link](https://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.1002128)

-   Rougier, N. P., Droettboom, M., & Bourne, P. E. (2014). **Ten Simple Rules for Better Figures**. PLoS Computational Biology, 10(9), e1003833 \| [link](https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003833)

-   Alla Katsnelson (2021). **Colour me better: fixing figures for colour blindness**. Nature 598, 224-225 (2021) \| [link](https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-021-02696-z)
:::

### Types of data visualizations:

-   Get some inspiration and code templates at [The R Graph Gallary](https://r-graph-gallery.com/)

### Going deeper

-   Wilke Claus 2019. Book: **Fundamentals of Data Visualization** \| [link](https://clauswilke.com/dataviz/)

### Choosing the right colors

-   Explore and choose the right color scheme ar R-color brewer \| [link](https://colorbrewer2.org/#type=sequential&scheme=BuGn&n=3)

-   Use Scico in R: color-blind friendly pallets to represent data fairly \| [link](https://www.data-imaginist.com/posts/2018-05-30-scico-and-the-colour-conundrum/)

-   Check if you figure is colorblind safe using this online simulator: [link](https://www.color-blindness.com/coblis-color-blindness-simulator/).

## Before writing your manuscript

Agree on authorship as soon as possible

-   Idiv - Molecular Interaction Ecology **Co-authorship Charte** \| [link](https://www.idiv.de/fileadmin/content/Files_MIE/202006MIE_coauthorship_chartervs3-website.pdf)

Scientific writing tips / guidelines

-   Turbek, S.P., Chock, T.M., Donahue, K., Havrilla, C.A., Oliverio, A.M., Polutchko, S.K., Shoemaker, L.G. and Vimercati, L. (2016), **Scientific Writing Made Easy: A Step-by-Step Guide to Undergraduate Writing in the Biological Sciences**. Bull Ecol Soc Am, 97: 417-426. \| [link](https://doi.org/10.1002/bes2.1258)

-   The British Ecological Society **Short Guide to Scientific Writing** \| [link](https://besjournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/hub/journal/13652435/journal-resources/guide-to-scientific-writing)

-   McGill (2016). BlogPost: **The 5 pivotal paragraphs in a paper.** \| [link](https://dynamicecology.wordpress.com/2016/02/24/the-5-pivotal-paragraphs-in-a-paper/)

-   Davis, Amy J., and Shannon Kay. 2023. **Writing Statistical Methods for Ecologists.** Ecosphere 14(5): e4539 \| [link](https://doi.org/10.1002/ecs2.4539)

-   Suggestions by a Nature science editor to make your paper fly through the review process \| [link](https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-019-01431-z)
